content: @WG-rustc-dev-guide we have a meeting in ~5 minutes
is there someone around to participate?
I forgot we have a meeting :sweat_smile: but yes I have time
@WG-rustc-dev-guide let's get started
@Joshua Nelson do you have something you want to discuss in particular?
not really no - I've been reviewing PRs but no major changes
:+1:
meeting is over
kidding kidding :)
:laughing:
so ... I guess we can discuss a bit next big goals
Nadrieril did write up https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/923 which is very interesting
and actually opened a big rustc PR while they were thinking about it
checking ...
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/78430

Joshua Nelson said:

Nadrieril did write up https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/923 which is very interesting

cool

Santiago Pastorino said:

so ... I guess we can discuss a bit next big goals

right, I got distracted
at some point we wanted to write an overview section
you mentioned a few times having a 'group brainstorming session' where we write up an overview what the compiler does start to finish
right
maybe that's a good idea
what do you think?
we have lots of reference material, I wouldn't be opposed to it but I think right now the guide needs the most work for helping get started
it's hard to find stuff about contributing itself - the reference for teh compiler is very good, but the contributing section is a little scattered
yes
well we discussed this a few times with mark-i-m
I think that rustc-dev-guide should be more about Rust internals
and some specific things about contributing maybe are better on forge
hmm
I'd always have a section on the guide for contributing but maybe more like an overview
with links to forge
it seems a shame to move again after moving contributing.md to the dev-guide :/
if we changed this we'd have to update all the links again, which I suppose isn't the end of the world
but it would be nice to have an end goal
who maintains forge?
which parts specifically are you talking about?

Santiago Pastorino said:

which parts specifically are you talking about?

https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/753

Joshua Nelson said:

who maintains forge?

I guess all of us :)
I guess my main concern is I want someone to have 'ownership' of the getting started guide
which, I'm fine if that person is me

Joshua Nelson said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

which parts specifically are you talking about?

https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/753

I believe most of that stuff is better if we have it on forge

Joshua Nelson said:

I guess my main concern is I want someone to have 'ownership' of the getting started guide

right
so ... the discussion at that time was about
having a rustc-dev-guide that look more entertaining and like a book
and less about procedures and such
we have/had stabilization of feature flags in the guide
which I guess should be better on forge too
and we can leave the guide for how the rust compiler works
right, all of that belongs together wherever it is
yeah
anyway, I'd put some or most of that stuff in rustc-dev-guide but more brief and with links to forge
we can have a get started chapter on the guide
cc @XAMPPRocky , how would you feel about having info about getting started with the compiler moved to forge? I think I've seen you merging PRs for forge
the other thing I'd like to do is walk through and read the intro material back to front
there's also compiler-team
and make sure that we're actually pointing people in the right direction
we had this discussion already with nikomatsakis and others
but I don't remember anymore what was the conclusion :)
The bigger forge is, the better IMO so I have no problem with it being there.
I think it was something like that
to slowly move procedures to forge
I guess we may want to have less in compiler-team or even kill it but I'd check this with nikomatsakis and/or pnkfelix

so here's my plan: sometime this weekend (after beating my head against https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/75114) I sit down with @Lokathor and move all this to forge, rewriting some of it in the process to make sure it actually makes sense
yeah I don't think anyone looks at compiler-team on github really
right
wait why me XD
@Lokathor I'm going to make you build the compiler only reading from the guide and see how confusing it is :P
fair
there may be procedures that we may want to move from compiler-team to forge too
anyway
(if this weekend is a bad time we can work out different times async)
that sounds like a good plan
anyway besides from contributing sections

Santiago Pastorino said:

there may be procedures that we may want to move from compiler-team to forge too

I think we should have the distinctions in mind: in my head there are three groups:
1. people who want a reference for this specific part of the compiler. this is the group looking a rustc-dev-guide
1. people who are just trying to get started. This info is going on forge
1. people already on T-compiler. This info is on https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/
I think procedures belong to group 3
well yes and no, I believe :P
I think things are a bit messy
but if you look at forge
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/index.html
forge was about documenting procedures for the different teams
and the compiler team slowly started to place things there
but there was also compiler-team
which I guess could just be the compiler team page or something like that
that just list working groups
meetings
etc
https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/
if you visit it, you will see procedures and there are 4 things there
I guess we can move that to forge
I would like it to be consistent one way or another :/
and just leave meetings information and working groups
maybe we should ask T-compiler?
yeah, anyway that's not part of what this group should do but we could :)
but if we were going to do something I'd move procedures out of compiler-team to forge
well, if we're moving content we need to know whether to move it to forge or compiler-team
I'd move contributing and procedures out of rustc-dev-guide to forge
ok that's one thing, what to do with procedures and contributing sections
the other thing I was thinking about is the overview or getting started section
I was imagining both the getting-started and contributing section going together
what I think I'd like to have is some high level explanations of the compiler example based
and hopefully combining them into one so the info is less scattered

Joshua Nelson said:

I was imagining both the getting-started and contributing section going together

right

Santiago Pastorino said:

what I think I'd like to have is some high level explanations of the compiler example based

like you start with some example code and have draws of what things look like after each transformation
maybe not just one example, maybe one per section but i guess you get what I meant
one example that fits everything may be hard
it would be cool to show all the -Z unpretty options side by side :)
exactly
and explain all that
to be honest I'm not sure how to do it because it may end being a huge chapter

error: argument to unpretty must be one of normal, expanded, identified, expanded,identified, expanded,hygiene, everybody_loops, hir, hir,identified, hir,typed, hir-tree, mir or mir-cfg

yeah that's most of the compiler right there :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

to be honest I'm not sure how to do it because it may end being a huge chapter

I think we should link to the different sections
and it may end being something that you would use to start with rustc-dev-guide but end explaining all the compiler before going into the details XD
and show people 'hey this is what MIR actually looks like, go look there for more info'
right, maybe that
actually another alternative is to put the unpretty output at the top of each chapter
but maybe one good proposal could be ... why don't we start and see how it looks like as a separate thing?
like where it says hir-tree right now: https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/hir.html

Santiago Pastorino said:

but maybe one good proposal could be ... why don't we start and see how it looks like as a separate thing?

I guess what I'm saying is ... why don't we look at the compiler high level, with examples and try to come up with structures, figures and unpretty output and then we can see where it fits

what I mean is ... I wouldn't go crazy now for where to put things on, one way or another what we need to do seems to be the same regardless if we create something new or we place those things in each existing section
right
so we can do this as a little side project and then integrate
yeah this does sound fun to write :)
right
we have 3 more minutes
so ... do you think we should schedule a time to work on this?
sure!
when would you want to start?
and how often?
you're in my time zone, right, east coast?
I'm in Uruguay, GMT-3
let's do a one-off thing for now and we can make it re-occuring if it goes well
yeah sounds good
does this time works for you?
maybe a bit later is even better for me
yup, this is good. If we do later I'd prefer not tomorrow or any monday
should we start next week?
so maybe next tuesday
I'd like to sit in as well, if that's all right
right now it's 5pm here
5pm works great

Iñaki Garay said:

I'd like to sit in as well, if that's all right

sure
great, so this time next week we'll work on the 'tour of the compiler' with unpretty and diagrams after the main meeting :)
and in the meantime I'll start on moving the getting-started guide to forge

Joshua Nelson said:

great, so this time next week we'll work on the 'tour of the compiler' with unpretty and diagrams after the main meeting :)

after the main meeting?
oh right we meet once a month
yeah or every 3 weeks
maybe we should redefine that too
I think it works well for the amount of activity
do you want to kill these scheduled meetings?
ok
great
we can start thinking async until next tuesday about some examples
I'm not sure how do we want to start
I think just going through all the -Z unpretty options would be a good start :)
for instance if there's something to show on the parser?
"this is what your code looks like when it's HIR"
I know unpretty can show HIR
it shows macro expansions too
nor sure about the AST
but can we show something above? like tokenizations? parsing? AST?
hmm ... @matklad do you know a debugging option for showing the AST?
well tokens maybe it's not worth I guess, unsure what do you guys think
or would you be interested in adding one?
Well, for rust-analyzer it's just rust-analyzer parse < my-rust.rs, but its probably not what you are looking for :-)
I meant for rustc itself, yeah :P
would be cool to show this from rust-analyzer though
@matklad where can I find the rust-analyzer binary? I have the extension installed
https://rust-analyzer.github.io/manual.html#vs-code
Look for "The server binary is stored in:"
oh that is a lot of output for the tokens :laughing:
thanks!
(lol, it is so satisfying to have documentation you can just LINK TO, like a pro )

@Santiago Pastorino here's some example rust-analyzer output:

$ rust-analyzer-linux  symbols < lib.rs
StructureNode { parent: None, label: "inner", navigation_range: 26..31, node_range: 22..53, kind: MODULE, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: Some(0), label: "S", navigation_range: 49..50, node_range: 38..51, kind: STRUCT, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: None, label: "inner2", navigation_range: 59..65, node_range: 55..148, kind: MODULE, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: Some(2), label: "f", navigation_range: 105..106, node_range: 98..146, kind: FN, detail: Some("fn() -> Vec<Box<S>>"), deprecated: false }
$ ~/.config/Code/User/globalStorage/matklad.rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer-linux  parse <<< 'fn main() {}'
SOURCE_FILE@0..13
  FN@0..12
    FN_KW@0..2 "fn"
    WHITESPACE@2..3 " "
    NAME@3..7
      IDENT@3..7 "main"
    PARAM_LIST@7..9
      L_PAREN@7..8 "("
      R_PAREN@8..9 ")"
    WHITESPACE@9..10 " "
    BLOCK_EXPR@10..12
      L_CURLY@10..11 "{"
      R_CURLY@11..12 "}"
  WHITESPACE@12..13 "\n"
the parse output is too verbose for a full source file but I think fn main() {} gets the idea across
(wow, rust-analyzer is so much faster than rustc)
and it does highlighting too, which I think counts as AST: image.png
yup, there's rust-analyzer highlight. And, if you open vscode, there's Show Rust Syntax Tree command as well
OMG, I want to merge rustc and rust-analyzer just so that I can have "show MIR" for the selected fragment of code...
I don't see 'show syntax tree' in 'command palatte', should I be looking somewhere else?
oh I think I need a folder open, not just a file
that would be a nice enhancement, to work without cargo

Joshua Nelson said:

Santiago Pastorino here's some example rust-analyzer output:

$ rust-analyzer-linux  symbols < lib.rs
StructureNode { parent: None, label: "inner", navigation_range: 26..31, node_range: 22..53, kind: MODULE, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: Some(0), label: "S", navigation_range: 49..50, node_range: 38..51, kind: STRUCT, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: None, label: "inner2", navigation_range: 59..65, node_range: 55..148, kind: MODULE, detail: None, deprecated: false }
StructureNode { parent: Some(2), label: "f", navigation_range: 105..106, node_range: 98..146, kind: FN, detail: Some("fn() -> Vec<Box<S>>"), deprecated: false }
$ ~/.config/Code/User/globalStorage/matklad.rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer-linux  parse <<< 'fn main() {}'
SOURCE_FILE@0..13
  FN@0..12
    FN_KW@0..2 "fn"
    WHITESPACE@2..3 " "
    NAME@3..7
      IDENT@3..7 "main"
    PARAM_LIST@7..9
      L_PAREN@7..8 "("
      R_PAREN@8..9 ")"
    WHITESPACE@9..10 " "
    BLOCK_EXPR@10..12
      L_CURLY@10..11 "{"
      R_CURLY@11..12 "}"
  WHITESPACE@12..13 "\n"

exactly, very cool :)
https://github.com/rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer/issues/6388

Hey @Santiago Pastorino something came up and I likely won't make the sync meeting we planned for this afternoon (3 PM EST). I might be able to make it a couple hours later, or we could reschedule a different day.

Joshua Nelson said:

Hey Santiago Pastorino something came up and I likely won't make the sync meeting we planned for this afternoon (3 PM EST). I might be able to make it a couple hours later, or we could reschedule a different day.

2hs later is fine otherwise next week
just in case 2hs later is at 2020-11-03T21:30:00+00:00, right?
let's move it to next week
next tuesday
@Joshua Nelson does 2020-11-10T21:00:00+00:00 works?
@Santiago Pastorino that works for me, sorry for the late notice
no worries, going to schedule it for next week at that time then on the compiler team calendar
@Joshua Nelson was thinking, maybe we need 1h for this?
what's the title of the meeting? :joy:
I was thinking that what we would be doing is something like rustc by example
maybe that works nicely for the purposes of what we try to do
the final result would be to make a better rustc-dev-guide but I guess we can start as a "side" document
if we need 1h I'd say let's start at 2020-11-10T20:30:00+00:00 and if we need 30 mins 2020-11-10T21:00:00+00:00 would be fine
I think if you want the full walkthrough an hour seems right
The first time works for me
(is there way to write timezone aware times on mobile?)

Joshua Nelson said:

(is there way to write timezone aware times on mobile?)

no idea
@WG-rustc-dev-guide have just added the event to the calendar
@Joshua Nelson check it out just in case our timezones math work correctly :)
Where's the calendar?

Joshua Nelson said:

Where's the calendar?

https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=6u5rrtce6lrtv07pfi3damgjus%40group.calendar.google.com
